content: Oh snap you managed to get it approved, congratulations! It was a long fought battle :D

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: As good as the first one and more complex. Good job !
Good puzzle, APPROVED, thanks for the good work!

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a great puzzle and I love Rummikub!
commenting for the achivement
cool

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Re-Approving

Resubmitting for another round. Some accompanying notes:
- Rummikub 1 is an approved medium puzzle - but for me it started with this contribution, and I only split it up in two parts because there is a case limit of 25 cases.
- In my humble opinion, Rummikub 1 and 2 combined is much nicer than only Rummikub 1. The Joker is a nice additional logical challenge, and there are several ways in which code can be optimized versus what is sufficient for Rummikub 1.
- Most of all, I look forward to seeing others solve this one and put my code length and run time to shame. I suspect that I am unaware of certain optimization possibilities, and that I approached this problem way too complex - with way too long solution code.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
There are some test cases without joker, does it mean it should work with the same solution as the first puzzle ? I got some timeouts ^^

Comment: Good part 2 that adds the Joker into the mix and makes it impossible to simply test every possible moves.
Lots of tests/validators to check every possible cases, great challenge for anyone that liked the first part.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Compared to the earlier version I have added a couple of cases (Don't use the joker; With J is better; Joker combine; Multiple takes with J; A lot of actions with J), but it are not fundamentally different cases, so I decided to try a round of 'Ready'.

Some insider info: there could be many more edge cases, that would require additional rules on which solution to select. I have now deliberately chosen to not include such cases. In other words: this is not an exhaustive contribution (it would be easy to construct cases that are part of Rummikub but not yet covered by the rules in this contribution). It is what it is.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

After bumping into the case-limit of 25 cases, I have decided to split the Rummikub contribution into two parts. This contribution is turned into Rummikub 2. The easier cases are moved to Rummikub 1. To make a relevant split, Rummikub 2 has the following differences:
- Rummikub 2 includes the Joker tile;
- Rummikub 2 has cases with more rows and more required steps. Where in Rummikub 1 you can solve the cases by simply trying all possible actions, that approach will time out in many of Rummikub 2's cases.
I hope the CG community agrees this is a Hard-level puzzle, and a valid separate contribution from the Medium-level Rummikub 1 contribution.

I keep this (and Rummikub 1) in WIP at the moment, because with this split into two contributions I can suddenly look for extra cases to include again :-). Feel free to suggest some!

I really like this puzzle.
So far I haven't started messing with Joker so I'm currently passing the 30 first tests.
My initial strategy was crashing due to memory issue on bigger tests, new one can pass everything easily.
Here's something I've noticed so far, there are no tests that check if your code handle the case where you need to combine in order take a tile when the tile you want is 'inside' a run (not the first or last tile of the run)
For example:

Input:
4Y
4
1 5G 5R 5Y
2 7B 8B 9B
3 6Y 7Y 8Y
4 2B 3B 4B 5B 6B

Output:
COMBINE 2 4
TAKE 5B 2
PUT 5B 1
TAKE 5Y 1
PUT 5Y 3
PUT 4Y 3
1 5B 5G 5R
2 2B 3B 4B
3 4Y 5Y 6Y 7Y 8Y
5 6B 7B 8B 9B

Input:
4Y
5
1 1G 2G 3G
2 7G 8G 9G
3 6Y 7Y 8Y
4 4G 5G 6G
5 5B 5R 5Y

Output:
COMBINE 1 4
COMBINE 1 2
TAKE 5G 1
PUT 5G 5
TAKE 5Y 5
PUT 5Y 3
PUT 4Y 3
1 1G 2G 3G 4G
3 4Y 5Y 6Y 7Y 8Y
5 5B 5G 5R
6 6G 7G 8G 9G

All the other cases I can think off seem to covered with existing tests, you did a great job with these.

Goal / Input / Output / Stub generator
* Any particular reason to use the term "stone"? I think the game pieces are called "tiles"? (No big deal really, it just sounds odd to me.)

* The following comments assume that "stone" is changed to "tile".

Goal
* Paragraph 1: Suggest to delete "All stones are available two times.", and then change the first sentence as follows:

Rummikub is a game played with tiles numbered 1-13 in four colors: {{B}}lue, {{G}}reen, {{R}}ed and {{Y}}ellow. There are two tiles of each number-color combination. There are also joker tiles, more on that below.

* Paragraph 1: Suggest to change "consists out of" to "consists of".

* Paragraph 1: Suggest to format "runs" and "sets" in <<bold>> when they're mentioned for the first time.

* Paragraph 1: Suggest to change:
"can be played on the table in runs (definition) or sets (definition)"
to (starting a new paragraph):
"Players play their tiles to form <<runs>> (definition) or <<sets>> (definition) on the table".

* Paragraph 2: Please change "little actions" to "few actions".

* Actions: Please add explanation of what TAKE and PUT do.

* Actions point 1: Suggest to change "a next" to "another".

* Actions point 3: Please change "put" to "{{PUT}}".

* Explanation of split: Please split "stonevalues" as two words (same as you did in the explanation of Joker).

* Action order point 3: Please add ";".

* Action order point 4: "use a J" is a bit vague. Maybe change that to "{{TAKE}} a J" (twice)?

* Suggest to change the heading "Action order" to a more general/wider-scope heading, as the rules involve more than just ordering. Maybe "Action selection and order"?

* Action order first sentence: Suggest to change "orders" to "series", and "following order" to "rules below".

* Note: Please change "shorted" to "shorter".

Input
* Suggest to change ", that combined" to "that".

* Line 1 mentions that [[putstone]] may be a joker, but there aren't such cases.

Output
* Suggest to change "that combined form the table" to "that are formed".

* Please mention that a row which becomes unused after {{COMBINE}} should not be output.

Cases
* Some tiles appear more than twice:
  ‚Ä¢ A lot is irrelevant (test): 2Y, 10G, 11G, 13Y
  ‚Ä¢ Validator 12: 2Y

* Please fix the rowids in input in Validator 22 and Validator 23 (currently not in order).

* Suggest to reorder the input so that the output actions do not concentrate on the first few rows (the simplest way is to move some last few rows to the beginning):
  ‚Ä¢ A lot is irrelevant (test) & Validator 12
  ‚Ä¢ Quite some actions, but a lot of extra (test) & Validator 15
  ‚Ä¢ A bit of everything (test) & Validator 22

* Optimization test: I don't understand how after "PUT J 16", the table "only contains valid runs and/or sets", if J is to be used as 7Y.

* Suggest, if possible and valid, to add cases where J has to be inserted as the leftmost tile (e.g. because there's an existing run of 2 to 13, or an existing set where B is the missing tile) or

The solution for ‚Äúoptimization‚Äù looks odd to me. You are combining rows 15 and 16 into a new row 15. A few steps later you put 6Y into row 15. I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs any way for row 15 to be able to accept 6Y at that point.

Definitely still WIP: I am planning to add more cases, and will reorder the cases later on more logically. And, I am in over my head - it might well be that I am overlooking edge cases (happens more often to me) or even am approaching coding Rummikub totally wrong.
I do already lift it out of Private now, because I am simply very curious what the CG community thinks about this one. Thanks in advance for your feedback!

Combining 15 and 16 leads to 1Y 2Y ... 7Y 8Y as new 15. You can add 6Y to this to get two valid runs 1Y ... 6Y and 6Y 7Y 8Y. The second one becomes the new run 21.
I gave an example for splitting by TAKE in the statement. I'll shortly add one for splitting by PUT, which happens here.

Oops, I've exceeded the word limit lol. Continued:

taken away (e.g. because there's an existing run of 1 to 13 where J is used as 1 or an existing set where J is used as B).

If such cases are added, the explanation of Joker in Goal section needs to be updated accordingly.

Thanks.

Thanks a lot for taking your time (again) for my contribution :-). As for your COMBINE to TAKE case, that's right - though it is partly covered in COMBINE to insert (case/val 9; there you must combine to do something in the middle of the middle row, which would be the same as when you would have to take that middle of the middle row).
And, I surely would like to include this one, BUT: I discovered yesterday there is a case limit of 25, which I have currently reached :-(. Based on that I would like to ask your thoughts on the following, if I may:

Potentially, I could turn this into two contributions:
- a Rummikub 1 contribution without J. Kind of the current cases 1-15 that you solved, but then with some extra edge cases, maybe also duplicate rows in there and/or that a step can be done equally from two distinct rows together with also a rule to select lowest rowid if you have multiple options, and a couple of longer cases). 
- a Rummikub 2 contribution (with higher difficulty level) that is all about J and optimization aspects (at least the optimization aspects that I have been able to tackle) - varieties of J use, and longer cases.
If I would split it in two, it means that with solving the difficult one, you also have the solution code for the easier one - and I don't like it when there are two contributions on Codingame that could use identical solution code. I prefer to have one complete contribution. However, with this one I got the feeling that due to the case limit I am not able to make it as complete as it possibly could be.

So, given that you started coding, some questions for you:
- If I would make two contributions as described above, what should the difficulty level of Rummikub 1 be (how 'hard' did it feel for you so far)?
- Do you have any opinion on one versus two contributions in this case?
Looks like I don't pass everything anymore, time to spend so time on this puzzle again :D
Cool! Can you also approve through the codingame system?üòä
Thanks for this third approvalüòÖ

Timeouts with Rummikub 1 code are to be expected. There are two axes along which Rummikub 2 is more difficult than Rummikub 1: longer cases (requiring code optimization), and the J. The J is introduced with a bunch of small cases to help test various J plays, but finally long and J are combined.

It works the other way around though: solution code for part 2 laughs at part 1.
Thanks for your fifth approvalüòÑ

*oh cool, a notification that someone commented my contribution, what compliment or good feedback will it be? So exciting --- oh nevermind*

Congrats with your achievement :-).

Ahh thanks! Just one more to go :-). Just out of curiosity, if you have your solution code at hand, how many ms does your code need for the final cases? Mine about 400-600 ms, but cedricdd's code a mere 7 ms if I remember correctly, so there is a huge optimization continuum (and/or I am approaching this puzzle inefficiently).
Thanks! I hope you quickly gain enough levels so that you can provide the approval through the system.üòä
Cool, thanks!
Yeah I started loosing hope, but a second approval quickly led to a thirdü•≥. I'm happy the two-part combi is now out there, and am very curious to see how others will solve it.
Well, after ten months since your first comments it's through! Thanks a lot for your support!

By the way, there are plenty of optimization options, and I definitely did not find them all. I settled for these cases: my code (Python) takes max 500-700ms for the longest ones. However, it could be (much) more extensive; cedricdd's code (php) apparently takes max 7ms. Looking forward to seeing more solutions and learning from themüòä.
OK thanks. I can optimize my code, I just wanted to be sure it was something to do. :)
Any success?

The holidays have been there, I haven't tried again since...
But don't worry I'll try ;)
Only one extra approval needed. No pressure.
Whoops. I did add a couple of cases, but I was not aware that they were much different. Which cases do you not pass?

"With J is better" & "Validator 14", I have the right actions but the COMBINE isn't done first.
"A lot of actions with J" & "Validator 17", I don't find anything currently.

Ah the first one is indeed a simple matter of correct sorting. And the second one you mention, I must admit, I just took case 2 ('A lot of actions') and added a J to it (hence 'A lot of actions with J'), so that might in fact be for some reason a case different from earlier cases (as in, maybe unknowingly in that one I put an extra edge).

Awesome that you're taking the time again. And I am glad that Rummikub 1 came through - hopefully Rummikub 2 now will also gain interest, but at least with Rummikub 1 we see some outcome of our hard work :-).

"A lot of actions with J" & "Validator 17" are not working because the J isn't placed where I was expecting it to be, since it's a set my code only checks if there's a Joker by checking the last position.

What it is currently: 10 10B J 10R 10Y
It works when I change the input with: 10 10B 10R 10Y J

"A joker is always displayed at the most right place, except if it fills a space inside a run"

Ah apologies for the mistake! I have corrected it now, thanks for finding the problem.

And you helped me see another error: for the new cases in some of the validators I had just shuffled the colors - but that put the set tiles in wrong orders. I have now fixed that as well; all sets in the input are ordered as  B G R Y (J).

When it comes to "With J is better" I've fixed it with very dirty hack that just moves the COMBINE in first position when there's one in the solution.
It works with all the tests/validators but it wouldn't be too hard to create a test where you need to combine but you can't do it as the first action.

Hah now you say so - every case with COMBINE has it as its first action. I thought 'no problem, lets force an extra action before that in one of the cases', but somehow I do not manage to manipulate the current cases in that way. I just looked at Rummikub 1: also there COMBINE is simply the first action. I think that in many cases, there is only a need to COMBINE if you can do it right away. If you force the COMBINE one step away, it makes the COMBINE redundant (for the cases that I have tried).
For example, 
1 1G 2G 3G
2 4G 5G 6G
and you would want to COMBINE in order to take the 1G.
I can manipulate this to make the COMBINE initially impossible by:
1 1G 2G 3G
2 5G 6G 7G
3 4B 4G 4R 4Y
(Before the COMBINE you now must take the 4G) --> but then the COMBINE is redundant because the 4G itself helps already to make the 1G free.

I need to think a bit about it more; let me see whether I can find a case that needs COMBINE where it can not be the first step, and if I find it, let me see whether I can squeeze it into an existing case or whether it warrants an additional case.

Nicely found by the way :-).

Ok nevermind I found a case. For example:
12B
5
1 6R 7R 8R 9R
2 11B 11G 11Y
3 8B 9B 10B
4 9R 10R 11R
5 9B 9G 9Y

EDIT: I can add this technique into the case 'Quite some actions, but a lot of extra' - but it forces extra rows to be involved, resulting in not so much extra after all; and it jumps my algorithm time consumption at that case from 800 to 1300ms. It would look like this; what do you think?
13Y
17
1 8B 8G 8R 8Y
2 10B 10G 10R 10Y
3 12B 12G 12R 12Y
4 6G 7G 8G
5 4B 4G 4Y
6 9G 10G 11G 12G
7 6B 6G 6R 6Y
8 9B 9G 9R 9Y
9 7R 8R 9R
10 2B 3B 4B 5B
11 5B 5G 5R 5Y
12 2R 3R 4R
13 7B 7G 7Y
14 6B 7B 8B
15 11B 11G 11R 11Y
16 1Y 2Y 3Y
17 4R 5R 6R 7R

12B
5
1 6R 7R 8R 9R
2 11B 11G 11Y
3 8B 9B 10B
4 9R 10R 11R
5 9B 9G 9Y

Is a really good find, my code is currently not able to solve it and is going to require a lot of changes :D
Hah oops. I imagine that the version of your code that did not put combine up front would be able to solve this one?ü§î

No the order of combine has nothing to do with it, I just don't manage at all the case where you need to remove a tile to be able to combine.
I don't try every possible actions, I start with the tile to add and only tests the actions that could end up with me being able to add it.
For example with:
3G
5
1 4G 4R 4Y
2 6G 6R 6Y
3 4B 5B 6B 7B 8B 9B
4 7G 8G 9G
5 5G 5R 5Y

1) I check for every rows if 3G could be added
2) when it reaches row 4 it finds a possibility so it searches for a 6G
3) I check for every rows if 6G could be taken
4) when it reaches row 2 if finds a possibility so it searches for a 6B
5) I check for every rows if 6B could be taken
6) when it reaches row 3 it finds a possibility, removing 7, 8, 9 wouldn't leave enough tiles to take the 6 so it just tries to remove the 4
7) I check for every rows if 4B could be added
8) ....

For 'Quite some actions, but a lot of extra' I'm solving it in ~3ms

Woww that's a beautiful algorithm. I have that approach built in loosely to decide which rows to use (and after that with those rows as sub-table I'm going to check all steps); I never thought of using that approach fully.

Are there any current cases that take your algorithm more than 100ms?
Currently the slowest is 'Validator 4' who takes 7ms

Lol I get the feeling I built this contribution around my algorithm (as in, the later cases are supposed to be harder for optimization, but that's only so for my algorithm), but that your algorithm is laughing at it allüòù.

And I guess it might not be possible to make it much harder for your algorithm, since in Rummikub it is rather limited what the possible options are for a given tile. At least, that's what I think at the moment, but I've to let it sink in a bit more. Really beautiful!

Edit: ah and I now see why the ordering is a bit of a nuisance for your algorithm. Mine basically checks all steps, gets all possible paths, and then I can pick the one with the right order. Yours however is wisely guided along a path, so you have to somehow implement that generic order into the wisdom (or solve it with an ugly hack).

I would say a lot of contributions are build around the submitter algorithm :D
Even if it's possible to solve quite fast, I still think it easily deserve the hard category.
Well making it work for the case where combine isn't the first action ended up not as hard as I expected, I think you should definitely add a pair of test/validator based on this case.

I have now altered the case 'A lot of actions and extra' + Validator 5 to force this mechanism. I decided against a separate case/validator pair for this mechanism - I feel that should have been part of Rummikub 1, and that this Rummikub 2 contribution is not anymore for any cases dedicated for specific dynamics (except for Joker dynamics).

Anyway thanks for finding another apparent edge again :-).
I get your reasoning, I've just tested and my solution for Rummikub 1 solves the case where combine isn't the first properly :D
And I like your typo; I always try to season my contributions well.
I have added the cases in order to pass the most recently modified tests, now my slowest is "Many paths to explore" in ~22ms

This contribution does not really get traction - I wonder why, because the Rummikub 1 puzzle seems liked well-enough, and I would somehow expect that people after solving that one would come and check out the Rummikub 2 puzzle.

But, as for you, is there a specific reason that you are holding off on approving (i.e. something that should be improved)?
No, I thought I did it, I just forgot :D
Don't worry about it right now; I will resubmit after 24 hours and then (if you still want :D) you can approve.
Ok, resubmitted it; let's see what this round of 30 days will bring. At least some upvotes came through, so who knows.

Hi,

I was not aware that there was a limit to the number of tests/validators, that sucks.

Even without handling the Joker this puzzle would be classified as a 'hard' puzzle IMO, I've already spend more time on it that what I spend on 'medium' puzzles.

Personally I don't have any issue when the code of a part 2 can be used to directly solve a part 1. The issue with a Rummikub 2 I could see would be about the amount of changes that are needed to properly handle the Joker when you have solved Rummikub 1 (is it enough to justify a separate hard puzzle).
I'm currently at the point where I've solved Rummikub 1, I'm now going to make the changes in order to handle the Joker and I will give you my final thought on Rummikub 2 when I can pass all the current tests.

Ah your insights (also the upcoming ones while you are solving J) are valuable. Because I tried to include J from the start, I do not precisely know the added difficulty level of J. If you find out that adding it is not too much work, I should make the split between version 1 and 2 somewhere else (maybe on only small cases where simple brute force can be applied versus bigger cases that require smarter path/row/tile selection), or not at all.

NB I'm glad that also without J you classify it as Hard. For two weeks I tried and miserably failed to build a full Rummikub algorithm. Defeated, I settled for rules like one TAKE one PUT. The fact that with those rules someone still classifies it as Hard, makes the defeat by the full Rummikub feel less bad :-).

Quick remark:

In "Don't use the joker" there's a line missing in the output:
17 12B 12G 12R 12Y

In "Validator 24" there's a line missing in the output:
14 2B 2G 2R 2Y

Ok there was not supposed to be any duplicate row in there (that case was originally with a lot of duplicate rows, but I decided to let that aspect go - those rows I overlooked). I need to check why my solution code does not print those rows, but anyway now I have deleted rows 17 and 14 from the input without changing the output.
Thanks!

FYI: I tried the COMBINE to TAKE setup as suggested by you, and found an error in my solution code because of that. I fixed it rather ugly (but it works now); more importantly:  I have changed the 'Joker inside' case such that the J can be taken only after combining. Because this is now slightly more challenging than 'Joker outside', I switched those cases, so the revised case is now test/validator 19 (37/38), which originally was 18 (35/36). Anyway, your suggested dynamic is now covered.

Another question:
What happens to this? 
8B
1
1 6B 7B J 9B 10B

1)
PUT 8B 1
1 6B 7B 8B 9B 10B J

2)
PUT 8B 1
1 6B 7B 8B
2 9B 10B J

3)
PUT 8B 1
1 6B 7B J
2 8B 9B 10B

Answer 1 happens to that. I'll try to cover that better in the rules, I agree that the current statement is ambiguous on this point (something like 'a split only happens when an identical tile is placed', and I meant it also somewhat with 'value of J is never fixed').

EDIT: I did not add it to the split rules, because the Joker is not yet explained there. Instead, I rephrased under the Joker paragraph: "The actual value of {{J}} is never fixed (while displayed as {{3R 4R J}}, it is not fixed whether {{J}} is {{2R}} or {{5R}} in this run; also, adding {{5R}} to the run {{3R 4R J 6R 7R}} does not split the run, since {{J}} is not fixed as {{5R}})."

In test 49 there's still a duplicate, row 12 & 14
In test 50 there's still a duplicate, row 16 & 17
Thanks! Removed the duplicate row in both tests.
Ok I'm passing all the tests now, next step will be to clean my code and gather my thoughts about the split.
I'm very curious, the suspense is killing meüòÖ. I wonder whether the cases feel wide enough for you, or that I for example unintendedly skewed them towards my algorithm.

So on the time it took me from passing all the tests before Joker to passing all the 50 tests I would say the time I've spend working on managing Joker specifically was like 25%, the rest of the time I was fixing code not related to Joker and handling more cases also not specific to Joker.

For example my code could not resolve this:
6B
3
1 4B 5B 6B 7B
2 3B 3G 3R 3Y
3 5B 5G 5R 5Y

For the tests with Joker there are also cases not covered, for example I was passing everything without managing something like that:
9G
3
1 4G 5G 6G 7G
2 4B J 6B 7B 8B
3 4G 4R 4Y

The extra tests you would get by having two contributions would be useful to check for the cases that are currently not tested, I'm pretty sure there are others that could be found.
Another advantage of splitting into two contributions is that sadly the chances of your puzzle being approved would be higher. (You need two other persons to take the time to solve it, even without the Joker it's an hard puzzle and there aren't a lot of people approving puzzles)
As for Rummikub 2, I don't think just adding the Joker is enough to justify for another puzzle, you probably would want to  add more stuff if you can.

Hmm what to do, what to do.
- The fact that you spent time on cases that are in itself not yet covered in this puzzle, confirms for me that this puzzle is in it's current state not complete (it is possible to succeed for all test cases with solution code that would fail in equally valid other cases).
- The extra cases do also not have a clear characteristic that I could simply exclude by adding some rules.
- This makes me more in favor of a split into two contributions - but where to put the split remains then the biggest question.

I think I am going to try to make one Medium contribution, without Joker, and just covering the basic techniques (like the first 10 current cases), with some more variations of those in there, and maximum up to five steps. It will be explicitly a stepping stone to the second (Hard level) contribution, which will include all aspects of the current contribution. In that Hard contribution, the case limit of 25 will be enough to cover the current edges, some variations on those, and the ones you found along the way, because the first 10 cases of the current contribution are moved to the Medium contribution.

For your information, I have now made Rummikub 1, and turned this one into Rummikub 2. I still want to add some cases to both of them (your suggestions are highly welcome!). I am also curious whether you agree that the new Rummikub 1 is a Medium-level contribution. For my own idea, I have cleaned away all Joker steps and many optimization steps from my code for Rummikub 1 - it easily solves all cases there while it quickly times out in Rummikub 2.

Apart from that, I am playing with the idea to include in Rummikub 2 a rule on how to deal with multiple rows that can be used for the same technique, and to include row combinations like
4Y 5Y 6Y 7Y
4B 4G 4R 4Y
and the need to take 4Y (with the rule that you have to take from the lowest rowid when there are multiple options). I am not yet sure whether I like that dynamic, though - it has nothing to do with the real Rummikub (in the real Rummikub it simply does not matter from which row you would take; only for our coding environment we need to be consistent).

As always, your feedback is great! I feel a bit lazy when I just copy your suggested changes - but they are simply too good not to use. I have implemented everything, except for the suggested changes on cases - for that I will take a bit more time.

Some specific remarks:
* Stones versus tiles: ah, my first language is Dutch, in which we use *steen* - literal translation *stone*, but of course it must be tile. For the starting tile I have shifted to the name [[goalTile]].
* Input Line 1 mentioning the Joker: that is because there I explain how a tile is displayed. I do not find the case 'J' as goalTile interesting. However, I do think that at that line it is the most logical place to introduce how tiles are displayed - and it feels incomplete not to mention the 'J' there. Any suggestion on changing the location of this? Personally, I do not think it is too big a problem if I suggest 'J' can be input, but in fact it never is.
* Optimization test: with {{PUT J 16}}, row 16 becomes {{5Y 6Y 7Y 8Y J}} (J can be 4Y or 9Y here, but is according to the rules displayed to the right). Then later on, {{PUT 6Y 16}} results in a split, with two runs {{5Y 6Y J}} (row 16) and {{6Y 7Y 8Y}} (row 21). Another way of seeing this is that we have {{J 5Y 6Y 7Y 8Y}}, with which a split by {{PUT}} with the middle stone is possible. This we do ({{PUT 6Y 16}}, resulting in {{J 5Y 6Y}} and {{6Y 7Y 8Y}}. In displaying these runs, however, J is always shown at the right side. In other words: J is always displayed to the right, but that does not mean that J equals that value (it can just as must be the left value - depending on the need).

...and one remark in a separate comment, because also I exceeded the word limit. I must admit: your exceedance was because you made a lot of valid points, while mine is simply because I use a lot of words. It is what it is.

* The case to have J as leftmost tile can only be created if J is the goalTile and there is only one run with space left ending at 13 (eg. 11Y 12Y 13Y). As earlier said, I do not find the case with 'J' as goalTile interesting (it would only be this single case with one row, and it requires a solution that is not necessary in any of the other cases). If another stone than 'J' is the goalTile, there is only a reason to put J leftmost if your goalTile is to the left of that  (eg. 11Y 12Y 13Y with goalTile 9Y would require J to be put at 10Y). However, that intermediate step of putting J leftmost will never be visible; the table is only displayed after putting goalTile. There is no other reason to put J leftmost - if your goalTile is related to another location without the need of 'J', there is never a reason to replace 'J' to some other position where it would need to be leftmost.
As for the set case, I decided that there 'J' is always displayed rightmost anyway (so, it would be {{3G 3R 3Y J}}). The reason for this is: it is most straightforward to always display rightmost. Only in the case of 'J' filling a place inside a run, this is not preferable (3Y 5Y J does not look good), so that it the only exception I created. In fact, I would not even care too much about {{12Y 13Y J}} -- the only rules are a maximum number of 13 tiles for a run and 4 tiles for a set. The fact that there is no 14Y, should not necessarily mean that J cannot be a 14Y. 
And also with a set: there is actually never a reason to add a 'J' to a set, except if it would be a goalTile. Any existing set is at least 3 tiles, and if you cannot add the goalTile to this, there is never a reason to add another tile to it. You do add a fourth tile to a set to take one of the existing ones - however you would never add a J as fourth tile to a set in order to take an existing 4Y - if you want to use 4Y and have a J, you could simply directly use the J as 4Y.

Ok, I can think of one case with J not as goalTile but still possible forcing a leftmost situation: goalTile 12Y, runs 1Y 2Y ... 12Y 13Y and 5B 5G 5R J. This would need to become 1Y 2Y ... 12Y and J 12Y 13Y (or, according to my bold statement above, 12Y 13Y J). I am hesitant about the added value of this case - and whether it is relevant to include in the statement that J can never by 14 or that J must be displayed leftmost if the most right stone is 13 to force a leftmost situation); what do you think?

And I do have one confession: my code is not optimized enough to handle all cases that are technically possible.  My code times out if I include *many* rows that are potentially helpful to the final solution and that offer a lot of TAKE and PUT possibilities. The optimization case is close to the max of what my code can handle (I am trying to optimize more, and brought runtime down to 3 seconds) - but I can construct a case that my code cannot handle. In your opinion: is that a problem (is it a problem that I partly choose the cases according to my algorithm)?

Thank you for your feedback! OK, now I know the story of tiles becoming stones. üòõ

Regarding your question of Input:
* I understand your reasoning. I would suggest to:
  ‚Ä¢ Line 1: change "tile" to "non-Joker tile" (twice).
  ‚Ä¢ Line 1: delete "- or J, indicating a joker".
  ‚Ä¢ Next nrow lines: change "tiles" to "tiles (a non-Joker tile or a Joker tile, indicated by {{J}})".

Regarding your comment on the Optimization test:
* I haven't realised, until now, that a joker tile may be moved around in a run when another tile in the same run is added or removed, and yet that doesn't need any {{TAKE J}} or {{PUT J}} action. Indeed that's shown in the first Joker test case. Maybe it's a good idea to add a sentence to explain that, or maybe not‚Ä¶ I'm not sure.

Regarding your comment on J being used as the leftmost tile:
* Your explanation is sound, except that I don't like the notion that "The fact that there is no 14Y, should not necessarily mean that J cannot be a 14Y." But this is your puzzle, so you can set the rules any way you like.

* However, if in the future there are cases where a joker tile must be treated as a 14, please mention that in the statement.

* Also, the current description in Goal section does make a very careful observer wonder why a joker tile can only be displayed at the right or in the middle, but never at the left. I think we can leave it at that for now, and see if other moderators have any views about that treatment.

Regarding your last question
* As the CG platform forces you to pass every test and validator before your contribution can even be uploaded, there's a limitation of what cases you can include in it. In my opinion, it isn't a big issue as long as your cases have a reasonable coverage of the possible cases in general. And you do have a variety of cases.

* Maybe when you can come up with an improved algorithm, you can create a Part 2 of the puzzle in the Very Hard difficulty category!

Comments on the revised version:

Goal section

Cases

Thanks.

* Yay, you've explained very clearly what I've been thinking about shuffling J without any explicit actions! If you consider for display purpose *always* displaying {{J}} at the right no matter what tile it stands for, that may make it more like a wildcard? In comparison, when you specify {{J}} to be displayed at a particular position, that seems to imply {{J}} stands for a particular tile.

Or maybe it's a thing that I should just twist my mind and get used to ü§™

* Ah, I've definitely missed that explanation of TAKE and PUT, as usually available actions are presented one by one. May I suggest to change the first sentence like this?
One action can be:
‚Ä¢ {{TAKE}} [[tile]] [[rowid]]: take a tile from a row,
‚Ä¢ {{PUT}} [[tile]] [[rowid]]: put a tile in a row, or
‚Ä¢ {{COMBINE}} [[rowid_1]] [[rowid_2]]: combine two rows.

* Noted on the outstanding issues (and note to myself: first round of my comments on cases).

Thanks!

* Regarding displaying J: I have been playing with the idea of *always* displaying J to the right, but somehow it does not feel nice to show 3Y 5Y J. However, J as wildcard has a much higher priority - that aspect I will keep in for sure, while displaying position is of less importance to me. I think I'll wait with this one on some feedback from other community members and my own thoughts over the coming days.
May I add that your decision on how J is positioned should apply to input as well for consistency.

I have updated the cases:
- Shuffled the input rows at the cases with multiple rows, so that the solution is not mainly based on the first rows / logical order of rows;
- Changed cases such that in all there are maximum 2 identical stones.

For now, I have decided not to put in the J-leftmost or max 4/13 testing. I think there are already quite a lot of cases, and the interesting aspect (in my opinion) is in how to find the correct solutions. If I include cases that test the statement rules to the letter, those cases will be the less interesting ones - so for now I keep them out. I did add the following sentence to the Joker paragraph: "The actual value of J is never fixed (while displayed as 3R 4R J, it is not fixed whether the J is a 2R or a 5R in this run)."

Also, I added one bigger case at the end with a lot of duplicate rows. For that, I also added in the statement "- If multiple rows can be used for the same action, use the row with the lowest rowid."

All right, sounds good to me.

Goal
* Actions: I don't suggest to separate the three possible actions (the ‚Ä¢ ones). I suggest to group them together for easier comprehension, and then add a newline before the additional specifics (the -- ones).

* Joker: Please format "J", ""2R" and "5R" as {{constants}}

Constraints
* I think the first constraint may be removed. For most of the CodinGame puzzles, this is implied. I think mentioning is needed only when the problem space contains cases where there are multiple solutions, but only those cases with a *unique* solution are chosen for the puzzle.

I'm raising this now because the addition of the multiple row rule has made me review the constraints again. I don't think there are unique solutions for this puzzle, the multiple row rule means that we're guiding the player to choose one of the possible solutions for the final output.

Cases
* Multiple row rule: Is the newly added pair the only cases where the rule is applicable? If so, I would suggest to modify one or two of the earlier pairs (e.g. pair 12) so that the rule needs to be applied there as well. Reasons: 1. Better to have rules introduced one by one earlier. 2. Don't waste the rule, heehee.

* Multiple row rule: Are there cases where this rule applies even though there are not duplicate rows? For example, goalTile is 5B, and there are rows of 6B 7B 8B, 2B 3B 4B and 5G 5R 5Y. If there aren't such cases, would it be a good idea to add them?

* row reordering: Would you please reorder the input rows in Validator 15 so that the output actions do not concentrate on the first half of the rows?

Thanks.

* Goal remarks: processed
* Validator 15: rows shuffled
* First constraint: removed

As for the multiple row rule: I started this contribution with the idea to only include cases with unique solutions. I recently added the final test/validator because it was one that I earlier failed with, but later on achieved with the (rather simple) optimization to ignore duplicate rows -> hence the need for that additional rule. I do agree with you that if I keep this last one in, I should make sure the rule is relevant in more cases - which brings me to that I need to think about whether I find this added dimension interesting enough or not. If it stays in, it is definitely also applicable to multiple distinct rows that all can accept the same tile, and frankly I am not sure whether I find that an interesting aspect.  At the moment, there are no other cases where this plays a role.
Simply selecting lowest rowid in a small case I do not find very interesting. That aspect becomes only interesting when the choice between different rows is buried somewhere deep in all the possible steps, and for that reason the player will need to keep track of not only the path found to the solution, but also the equivalent paths along the way, in order to select the final solution path based on the given rules (COMBINE as early as possible, no J, J as early as possible, and finally lowest rowid's first).
NB: the need to select out of several solutions is currently present in the final case: after removing identical rows there are 257 unique solutions to that one, which is mainly because of the J in row 1 that can be or not be replaced by a 12Y at any point. Interestingly, J is never technically taken there, so I will have to adjust the rules to select a solution without using J in any way (which can be to TAKE, or even to replace within a row).
